<div class=Section1>

<h1 align=left style='margin-left:0in;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;
mso-list:none;tab-stops:.5in'><!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'><span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes"> </span>TC "Chapter 3" \f C \l "1" </span><![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span></span><![endif]--><span
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>L</span>ab # 3 Part 1<!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span> TC "Chapter 1" \f C \l
"1" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]-->-
Experiments for the 5<sup>th</sup> Week<!--[if supportFields]><span
style='font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span></span>
TC "<span style='font-weight:normal'>Experiments for the 3rd Week</span>"
\f C \l "1" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span></span><![endif]--><span
style='font-weight:normal'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>This lab covers the following Chapter in the text: 3.4.</p>

<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in;mso-list:none;tab-stops:.5in'>Objectives<!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span> TC "3.1	Objective" \f C \l
"2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l5 level1 lfo7;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Static or Fixed Routing</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>Note</b>: Understanding of IP routing prior to your laboratory session
is essential for this week’s experiments.</p>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='text-align:justify'>Cisco has some useful info on
their website on routing.</p>

<p class=MsoBodyText><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman"'>http://www.cisco.com/univercd/cc/td/doc/product/software/ios121/121cgcr/ip_c/ipcprt2/index.htm</span></p>

<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Times;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-ansi-language:EN-US;mso-fareast-language:
EN-US;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA'><br clear=all style='page-break-before:always'>
</span></b>

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>Static Routing<!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:
field-begin'></span> TC "3.5	Static Routing" \f C \l "2"
<![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Every routing decision is made by
the routing table look-up. The routing table can be updated by a routing daemon
(dynamic routing), ICMP redirect message, or the command that manipulates
routing table entries (static routing).</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>A static route is one that you
enter explicitly using commands. To build the routing table in your PC, the
route command is used. Routing entries that are created manually don’t usually
change, even if you run a routing daemon. Static routes are often added from
the system startup script.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>Routing table for PC<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Your PC’s routing table can be
displayed with the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>netstat</b> command.
We list the commands that are used to manually build the routing table in your
PC.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>netstat -rn</b> : displays the routing table in the system.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>route add -net</b><i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>
destination_net_address </i><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-style:italic'>netmask</span></b><i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'> mask </i><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-style:
italic'>gw</span></b><i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'> gateway_address:</i>
adds a new route to the routing table via a particular gateway, specifies the
mask to be used for this entry. (<b>-host</b> will enter a host entry and one
does not specify a netmask<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>for that.)</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>route del –net</b><i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>
destination_net_address</i>: deletes an existing route from the routing table</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>All the arguments are
self-explanatory. For more details see the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>man</b>
pages.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>Routing table for Router<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>You can manually configure the
router’s table. In order to see the IP routing table in the router, in the
privileged-level mode, type the following command:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>router_name# show ip
route<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>The following commands are used
to modify the routing table entries in the router. Type the following commands
in the configuration mode. Read last lab’s “Configuring Router” section on how
to get into the configuration mode.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>ip route</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>destination_address
netmask router_address</i> : creates a route to <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>destination_address</i> via <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>router_address</i>.
The argument <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>destination_address</i> is
the IP address of the <u>target</u> network, and the argument <i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>router_address</i> is the address of a
router that can reach <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>destination_address</i>
. The <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>mask</i> gives the mask to be used
for the destination address.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>no ip route</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>destination_address
router_address</i> : removes a route from the IP routing table.</p>

<h3><![if !supportLists]>1.1.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span><![endif]>A Single Router Experiment</h3>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>For this experiment we will only
be using a single router and two PCs connected via hubs to the router
interfaces. Use the table below to set the IP addresses for the two PCs and the
router. Note that because we are using a router, each interface has a different
IP net address (compare to the bridge setup).</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

  </td>

  mso-border-top-alt:double windowtext 1.5pt;mso-border-left-alt:double windowtext 1.5pt;
  padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>

  </td>

  border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;border-right:double windowtext 1.5pt;
  mso-border-top-alt:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>
  </td>
  <td width=125 valign=top style='width:1.3in;border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;
  mso-border-top-alt:double windowtext 1.5pt;mso-border-left-alt:double windowtext 1.5pt;

  none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;border-right:double windowtext 1.5pt;

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:2.0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
.5in'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Table 3.1: IP addresses for Figure
3.1<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Use setup from the console window
to configure the router. If you disable bridging, ip routing is enabled. Do not
enable any of the routing algorithms as we are using static routing and will be
entering the routes manually! If you use the configure command instead to set
up the router, you must enable routing by typing</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b>ip routing<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>at the configure command.. As the
router is directly connected to the only two subnets <u>no</u> manipulation of
the router’s routing table is required at this point. Use the command:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b>show ip
route <o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText3>at the enable prompt to display the routing table.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Next you must setup the PC
routing tables. As<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>they are both connected
to an Ethernet to which only one router is attached, we can use the default
entry to route all traffic not local to its subnet via the router. First check
your PC routing tables using the <b>netstat –rn</b> or <b>route</b> commands.
Then use the command:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b>route add –net</b>
<i>0 </i><b>gw</b><i> 154.81.51.1</i></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText3><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText3>on Host_A and the command:</p>

<p class=MsoBodyText3><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b>route add
–net</b><i> default </i><b>gw</b><i> 154.81.52.1</i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>on Host_B. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal>Now use the command <b>netstat –rn</b> or <b>route</b> on
both PCs to check your routing tables. The “<u>0</u>” destination net address
used in the command above reflects the <u>default</u> route (one can also type <i>default</i>).
For default route you do not give any netmask. Note that the position of a
routing entry indicates its search order. Whenever an IP device needs to route
an IP datagram, it uses the routing table and searches thru it systematically
starting with the first entry. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Exercise 1</u></b><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>       </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Run <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>tethereal –V </b>on your machine, and <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>tethereal –V </b>on the other machine in the other subnet at the same
time. Send <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ping</b> messages to the
other machine<i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>. </i>After receiving the
tenth echo reply, quit the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ping</b>
process and save the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tethereal </b>outputs
for both machines.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></u></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Questions #1:</u></b><span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo4;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>When a packet is sent to a PC in the other subnet,
explain how the source and destination Ethernet addresses are changed.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo4;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>What are the source and destination addresses in the IP
and Ethernet headers of a packet that goes from your machine to the router? </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo4;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>What are the source and destination addresses in the IP
and Ethernet headers of a packet that goes from the router to the other
machine?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo4;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Answer the same questions, but for the echo reply that
is returned from the other machine.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo4;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Show the routing tables for both PCs.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><u>Exercise 2:<o:p></o:p></u></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Add to Host_A’s routing table the
following entry:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b>route add
–net</b> <i>154.81.52.0 </i><b>netmask</b><i> 255.255.255.0 </i><b>gw</b><i>
154.81.51.1</i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Now check the routing table using
<b>netstat –rn </b>or <b>route (-e </b>will give same output as<b> netstat –rn </b>and<b>
–ee </b>will give everything!).</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><u>Questions #2</u>:<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<ul style='margin-top:0in' type=disc>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-list:l16 level1 lfo45;
     tab-stops:list .5in'>Compare the two routing tables, prior to and after
     the route addition.</li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-list:l16 level1 lfo45;
     tab-stops:list .5in'>Will this new entry make a difference? Explain what
     happened to the routing table.</li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-list:l16 level1 lfo45;
     tab-stops:list .5in'>Explain the flags associated with the entries in the
     routing table.</li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-list:l16 level1 lfo45;
     tab-stops:list .5in'>If you added a host entry for Host B instead, what
     would it look like in the routing table? Explain the associated flags and
     its position in the table.</li>
</ul>

<h3><![if !supportLists]>1.1.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span><![endif]>A 4 Subnet Experiment</h3>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>In this experiment, we divide the
network into four subnets. There will be one machine in each of the following
subnets, 154.81.51.0, 154.81.52.0, 154.81.53.0 and 154.81.54.0. As shown in
figure 3.2, we will connect the four subnets (154.81.51.0, 154.81.52.0, 154.81.53.0,
and 154.81.54.0) using three routers.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>In order to configure the new
network topology, we need to change the current IP addresses of each PC
interface card. The new IP addresses that we want to use are as shown in the
figure. (Note that 52.100 is an abbreviation for 154.81.52.100. This notation
applies to all the PC and router addresses given in the figure above.)</p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
.5in'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Figure 3.2: Topology for static
routing<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Exercise 3</u></b><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>       </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Change the IP addresses of the
PCs to reflect the network configuration as shown in figure 3.1. Also configure
the routers. Save the output of <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>netstat
-rn</b> or <b>route –ee</b> before building the PCs’ routing tables. After
examining figure 3.2, build the static routing table in all the PCs manually.
Use <b>netstat –rn</b> or <b>route –ee</b> to verify your entries.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText3>Save the routing tables of all the routers before
building any routes. Note: You cannot telnet into the routers as they are on
different subnets and the routing tables have not yet been entered. You need to
use the console to configure each router.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Now configure the routing table
in each router using the <b>ip route</b> command (e.g., <b>ip route</b> <i>154.81.51.0
255.255.255.0 154.81.52.1</i> will add the “51” subnet address to router 2’s
table indicating that the router with port address 154.81.52.1 must be used as
the next hop router). Note, as mentioned above, you must set <b>ip routing</b>.
Recall that we set it to <b>no ip routing</b> to do bridging in last week’s
experiment.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Use the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>ping</b> and <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>traceroute</b>
programs to test the connections. Save the <b>traceroute</b> outputs.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>When you can reach other hosts successfully, save the
routing tables of all the PCs and in the routers for the lab report. (Even if
the routing table in your PC is correct and all the routers are configured
perfectly, you may not get the connection to one of the other PCs. If this is
the case, the routing table in the other PC should be blamed. When you can get
the ping reply messages from all the interfaces in the PCs and routers
successfully, your work is done for this exercise on static routing.)</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Questions #3</u></b>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span></p>

 <li class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-list:l13 level1 lfo44;

 <li class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-list:l13 level1 lfo44;

     routing tables after configuration). Your explanation should include the
     meanings of the flags that appeared, and the routing function of each
     entry. </li>
</ul>

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>Experiments with ICMP and Routing<!--[if supportFields]><span

style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Use the same network configuration
as you did for the Static Routing experiment (Figure 3.2) </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.4in;text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText3><b><u>Exercise 4:<o:p></o:p></u></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-indent:.4in'>Empty the routing table of PC
154.81.52.100 by typing: <b>route flush</b>. Then add a default routing entry
to gateway 154.81.51.1. Check the routing table by typing: <b>netstat –rn</b>.
Save the contents. Run <b>tethereal</b> in a window on PC 154.81.52.100. Then <b>ping</b>
from PC 154.81.52.100 to PC 154.81.53.100. Immediately after <b>ping</b>
returns with “an alive” message check the routing table. Save the contents.
Wait a few minutes then check the contents of the routing table again and save.
Also save the <b>tethereal</b> output.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.4in;text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText3><b><u>Questions #4:<o:p></o:p></u></b></p>

 <li class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-list:l15 level1 lfo43;
     tab-stops:list .5in'>Compare the contents of the three <b>netstat</b>
     outputs. What do you observe? Discuss the different entries and the
     corresponding flags.</li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-list:l15 level1 lfo43;
     tab-stops:list .5in'>Analyze the <b>tethereal</b> output and explain what
     happens using the content of the <b>tethereal</b> file.</li>
</ul>

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.3<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>Routing Information Protocol (RIP)<!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span> TC "4.3	Routing Information
Protocol (RIP)" \f C \l "2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Although
there are many routing protocols, we will study one of the most common ones
that is used for intra Autonomous System routing (Interior Gateway Protocols),
the Routing Information Protocol (RIP). RIP is run by the routing daemon, <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>routed</b>, in your PC. The routing daemon
dynamically builds the routing table from the received RIP updates. The PCs
started <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>routed</b> at boot-up, no other
action is needed to run RIP on the PCs. (Note: if you make any manual changes
to the routing table (adds or deletes), <b>routed</b> will not touch manual
changes. For example, if you accidentally delete an entry in the PC routing
table, <b>routed</b> will not re-insert it. You have to kill the routed process
(use: <b>ps –ef<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>| grep routed</b> to
get the process ID, then <b>kill </b><i>process</i><b> (</b><i>process</i><b> </b>here
refers to the process ID), and then restart it using: <b>in.routed –q</b>).</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>To enable a routing process for
RIP on all interfaces in a router, use the following commands when in
configuration mode. Refer to the “Configuring Router” section on how to get
into configuration mode.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>router rip<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>network</b> <i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>network_number</i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>network_number</i><span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>is
154.81.0.0 for this network configuration.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>To remove a network from the
list:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>no network</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>network_number</i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>To shut down the routing process:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>no router rip</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText3><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Note again that
any routes that were added manually will not be updated by RIP.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></u></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></u></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Exercise 5<o:p></o:p></u></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Empty all the routing tables in
the PCs and the routers. Use Figure 3.2 again as the network configuration. Now
start the RIP process in the routers.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>After running RIP in all the
routers, test the connections to the other hosts using either <b>traceroute</b>
or <b>ping</b>. Once you can successfully reach all the hosts, save one of the
RIP messages using <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tethereal –P udp -V</b>
in each subnet. Save the routing table in one of the PCs.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>Figure 3.3: Rip Experiment<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Exercise 6<o:p></o:p></u></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Now connect the fourth router as
show in Figure 3.3. Use <b>netstat –rn</b> or <b>route –e</b> to observe the
changes that are being made to the routing tables. Save the output. Now disconnect
the two cables that connect router 4 to the two Ethernets. See approx. how much
time it takes RIP to alter the routing table in PC 52.100 to reflect the new
topology. (Hint: use <b>ping –s</b> from PC 154.81.52.100 to PC 154.81.54.100
and see how long it takes till the alive message comes thru again after the
disconnection. Check the routing table for new entries!)</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Questions #6</u></b>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo37;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Give the measured time from Exercise 6.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo37;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Compare the entries of the routing tables in the PCs
and the routers with router4 connected and disconnected.</p>

<h2 align=left style='margin-left:0in;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;
mso-list:none;tab-stops:.5in'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></h2>

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.4<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>Mixed Router – Bridge Experiment</h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>For this experiment you will configure two of the routers as
bridges and two as routers as shown in Figure 3.4 below.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<h2 align=center style='margin-left:0in;text-align:center;text-indent:0in;
mso-list:none;tab-stops:.5in'>Figure 3.4 Router – Bridge Experiment</h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>Four PCs are connected to 4 LANs (one PC per LAN). Two bridges<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>and two routers are interconnecting the 4
LANs. This a type “B” campus network and the network ID is: 132.143.<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><u>Exercise 7<o:p></o:p></u></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>Flush all the routing tables and run RIP. Only three bits
may be used for subnetting. Choose appropriate subnet IDs for the given configuration.
Assign IP addresses to the bridge and router interfaces and the 4 PCs.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><u>Questions #7</u></b>:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<ul style='margin-top:0in' type=disc>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-list:l14 level1 lfo47;tab-stops:list .5in'>What
     is the subnet mask for this subnetted network? </li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-list:l14 level1 lfo47;tab-stops:list .5in'>For
     each IP address that you assigned, identify the subnet ID and the host ID.</li>
</ul>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><u>Exercise 8<o:p></o:p></u></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>After RIP has run for awhile and you are able to reach all 4
PCs (use <b>ping</b> or <b>traceroute</b>), use <b>netstat<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>-rn</b> or <b>route -e</b> to show the
routing tables in the PCs. Save the outputs. While running <b>tethereal –V</b> on
PC1, PC2, PC3 and PC4, <b>telnet</b> from PC1 to PC3. Observe the packet flow
between the two PCs.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><u>Questions #8</u></b>:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<ul style='margin-top:0in' type=disc>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-list:l14 level1 lfo47;tab-stops:list .5in'>Give
     the routing tables of the 4 PCs.</li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-list:l14 level1 lfo47;tab-stops:list .5in'>Trace
     the flow of IP packets from PC1 to PC3.</li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-list:l14 level1 lfo47;tab-stops:list .5in'>Indicate
     the Ethernet and IP packet headers used on each LAN segment for the IP packets
     flowing between PC1 and PC3.</li>
</ul>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>
